content.title: Antithrombin Deficiency
content.summary: Antithrombin (AT, formerly antithrombin III) deficiency is an inherited thrombophilia with the highest VTE risk among the natural anticoagulant deficiencies (10-25× increased). Antithrombin is the major inhibitor of thrombin and factor Xa, and its activity is markedly potentiated by heparin. AT deficiency causes heparin resistance - the hallmark clinical clue. Acquired causes include liver disease, DIC, nephrotic syndrome, and heparin therapy. Treatment of acute VTE may require antithrombin concentrate to achieve therapeutic anticoagulation.
key_points: Highest VTE risk among inherited thrombophilias (10-25× increased)
AT inhibits thrombin and Xa; heparin works by enhancing AT activity 1000-fold
Heparin resistance is the clinical clue - PTT doesn't rise as expected
Acquired causes: liver disease, DIC, nephrotic syndrome, heparin therapy
Test with functional AT assay; affected by heparin and acute thrombosis
Treatment: AT concentrate may be needed to achieve therapeutic anticoagulation
content.statement: Antithrombin deficiency is the highest-risk inherited thrombophilia, characterized by VTE and heparin resistance due to deficiency of the major natural inhibitor of thrombin and factor Xa, with antithrombin concentrate required for treatment of acute thrombosis.

explanation.intuition: Antithrombin is the main 'brake' on clotting - it grabs onto thrombin and factor Xa and shuts them down. Heparin works by making antithrombin grab much faster (1000× enhancement). Without enough antithrombin, heparin can't work properly, and the clotting system keeps going.
explanation.key_insight: Heparin resistance is the clinical giveaway. If you're giving adequate heparin doses but the PTT doesn't rise, think about antithrombin deficiency. This is because heparin's anticoagulant effect depends entirely on having sufficient antithrombin.
explanation.technical_details: Antithrombin is a serine protease inhibitor (serpin) synthesized by the liver. It irreversibly inhibits thrombin, Xa, IXa, XIa. Heparin binds a specific pentasaccharide sequence on AT, causing conformational change that accelerates inhibition 1000-fold. AT deficiency types: Type I (quantitative), Type II (qualitative - reactive site, heparin-binding site, or pleiotropic mutations).

definitions_glossary.antithrombin: Major natural anticoagulant; serine protease inhibitor of thrombin and Xa
definitions_glossary.heparin_resistance: Failure to achieve expected anticoagulation with standard heparin doses
definitions_glossary.type_II_deficiency: Qualitative dysfunction with normal antigen levels
definitions_glossary.heparin_binding_site: AT domain where heparin binds to enhance activity
definitions_glossary.reactive_site: AT domain that interacts with and inhibits target proteases
definitions_glossary.AT_concentrate: Plasma-derived or recombinant antithrombin for replacement therapy
definitions_glossary.homozygous_AT_deficiency: Complete absence of AT; usually incompatible with life
definitions_glossary.acquired_AT_deficiency: Secondary reduction from liver disease, DIC, nephrotic syndrome
definitions_glossary.VTE: Venous thromboembolism; includes DVT and PE

normal_AT_function.mechanism: Forms 1:1 irreversible complex with thrombin, Xa, IXa, XIa

subtypes.heparin_binding: Mutations in heparin-binding domain; lower VTE risk

genetics.homozygosity: Usually lethal in utero; rare survivors have severe thrombosis

VTE_manifestations.age_of_onset: Often before age 40; may present in teens

heparin_resistance.clinical_clue: PTT doesn't rise with standard heparin dosing
heparin_resistance.mechanism: Heparin requires AT for anticoagulant effect

testing.functional_assay: Chromogenic or clot-based AT activity assay

interpretation.type_I: Both activity and antigen reduced proportionally

timing_considerations.best_timing: 2-4 weeks after anticoagulation stopped; off heparin
timing_considerations.confirmation: Repeat abnormal results; test family members

differential_diagnosis: Acquired AT deficiency (liver disease, DIC, nephrotic syndrome)

acute_VTE_treatment.challenge: Heparin resistance due to low AT

antithrombin_concentrate.indication: Acute thrombosis, surgery, pregnancy with AT <60%
antithrombin_concentrate.dosing: 50-100 IU/kg; adjust based on measured levels

acute_VTE_treatment.alternative: LMWH may work better than UFH (partially AT-independent)
acute_VTE_treatment.fondaparinux: Requires AT but lower doses may still work
acute_VTE_treatment.DOACs: Do NOT depend on AT; may be preferred for long-term

long_term_anticoagulation.duration: Often indefinite after first unprovoked VTE
long_term_anticoagulation.warfarin: Effective; does not depend on AT
long_term_anticoagulation.DOACs: Direct inhibitors; AT-independent; may be preferred

prophylaxis.AT_concentrate: May be used perioperatively with anticoagulation

pregnancy_management.risk: High VTE and pregnancy loss risk
pregnancy_management.treatment: LMWH prophylaxis or therapeutic; AT concentrate if levels very low

definition.@value: Inherited deficiency of antithrombin causing high VTE risk and heparin resistance

scopeNote.@value: Highest VTE risk among inherited thrombophilias; causes heparin resistance

learning_objectives: Explain the role of antithrombin in coagulation
Recognize heparin resistance as a clue to AT deficiency
Differentiate type I from type II AT deficiency
Describe management of acute VTE in AT deficiency
List acquired causes of reduced antithrombin
clinical_pearls: Highest VTE risk of inherited thrombophilias (10-25×)
Heparin resistance is the clinical clue - heparin needs AT to work
DOACs work independently of AT - may be preferred for long-term
Test off heparin; AT is consumed during acute clot
AT concentrate may be needed to achieve anticoagulation in acute VTE
common_misconceptions: All heparin resistance is from AT deficiency - many other causes exist
AT deficiency is common - it's actually rare (0.02-0.1%)
Homozygous AT deficiency is compatible with life - usually lethal in utero

evidence.confidence_rationale: Well-characterized genetic disorder with established management

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
